Chemical industry is facing an upcoming transition from fossil to renewable carbon feedstocks such as CO2. In this context, processes yielding value-added chemicals are of special interest. For the production of higher alcohols (C≥5), iron-based catalysts have been found to be promising. Herein a design of experiment study for the optimization of the space-time yield in dependence of the reaction conditions was conducted for a technically relevant shaped iron-based catalyst optimized for higher alcohol synthesis. In this context also the influence of CO2 on the catalytic performance was studied. In order to allow for an assessment of the catalyst performance in a Power-to-Liquid process, the influence of tail gas recirculation on selectivity and yield was evaluated in a scaled-up test plant. The results presented here provide valuable data for an upcoming techno-economic assessment of the whole Power-to-Liquid process chain. Graphical Abstract Keywords Higher alcohol synthesis Iron catalyst Process integration Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Shaped catalyst Power-to-Liquid Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Currently, fossil feedstocks are the basis of the chemical industry. In the context of global efforts to achieve CO2 neutrality in the coming decades, this sector must therefore undergo a transformation. One future goal is the production of chemical compounds from sustainable carbon sources such as CO2 (biogenic or captured from air) or biomass utilizing renewable energy in decentralized plants scaled according to the availability of the carbon source [1–7]. In addition to considerable investment costs, this also requires intensive development work, as in many fields there are still no alternative process routes based on renewable feedstocks available. While processes producing synthetic fuels such as kerosene in Power-to-Liquid plants are subject of current research efforts and already investigated in demonstration plants [8], the production of fine chemicals has so far often only been considered on catalyst level. However, while the production of kerosene might allow for a first technical implementation of Power-to-Liquid processes, the production of valuable chemical products is an important upcoming step on the transition pathway of the industrial sector. Among the broad variety of chemical products, alternative routes for the production of higher alcohols (HA) have gained increasing interest in the last years [9–12]. This is due to their relevance in different applications [13,14], their comparably high price [13,15] as well as their current production process. HA are currently produced from crude oil-derived olefins via hydroformylation or Ziegler-Alfol synthesis [13,14,16]. The envisioned transition away from crude oil makes a direct production pathway from sustainably sourced syngas attractive. The term higher alcohols is often used to describe alcohols with a chain length j ≥ 2 [9]. However, the inclusion of ethanol in this definition is not meaningful, as ethanol is accessible via other synthesis routes and is also used for other applications [13,14,17]. In this work, HA are considered to be compounds with a chain length of j ≥ 3. A special emphasis is laid on HA with chain length of j ≥ 5. This additional distinction makes sense, as the latter compounds differ significantly from propanol and butanol in terms of their properties. An important one is their solubility in polar and non-polar solvents. Higher alcohols are amphiphilic, as they have a non-polar alkyl chain and a polar hydroxyl group. As the chain length j increases, the influence of the terminal polar group decreases, and the lipophilic character predominates. From a chain length of j = 5, the alcohols dissolve almost quantitatively in non-polar solvents. On the one hand, this is relevant for the separation from the Fischer-Tropsch product phases, but on the other hand it is also relevant for the application of the higher alcohols [14]. The catalysts presented for the higher alcohol synthesis (HAS) from syngas are primarily bimetallic, modified methanol or Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalysts based on mixtures of Co, Cu, and Fe. Comprehensive reviews are given in Ref. [9,10,18]. The highest space-time yield (STY) for HA production of > 300 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 and > 100 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 have been reported for Co- and CuFe-based powder catalysts, respectively [19,20]. Although these powder catalysts show good performance in HAS, there are several drawbacks, namely the high reaction pressure (p ≥ 50 bar) and temperature (T ≥ 250 °C) as well as high selectivity towards CO2 and branched alcohols [21–23]. As the demand as well as the price for pure linear primary HA are high compared to isomeric mixtures of alcohols, a highly selective synthesis of these products and low complexity of the alcohol mixture produced are of advantage [13,15,16,24,25]. Furthermore, the price as well as the mining of cobalt under socially and ecologically critical conditions give rise to the search for catalyst materials with lower social and ecological impacts [26–28]. Therefore, monometallic iron catalysts have been focused as well in the last years due to their low cost, tunable selectivity to HA and low selectivity to CH4 and CO2 under milder conditions compared to the bimetallic systems [9,18,29,30]. Furthermore, iron catalysts are active in the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction (1) C O 2 + H 2 ⇄ CO + H 2 O ∆ r H 0 = 41 kJ mo l − 1 as well as the water-gas shift (WGS) reaction [31]. This could be advantageous in case CO2 is used as a carbon source. CO2 hydrogenation for alcohol synthesis has been studied in several publications [32–35]. A drawback is that a higher temperature is necessary in this case [33,36]. At these conditions especially the selectivity to long-chain alcohols is decreasing (Section 2.1). Therefore, the utilization of CO might offer advantages. Thus, a considerable number of publications utilizing CO can also be found in literature [9,10,12,21,37]. However, a technical syngas as it might be produced via coupling of electrolysis and RWGS or via co-electrolysis [4,7,38], typically contains 10–15 % CO2 [4,7,38,39]. So far, studies considering such a syngas can rarely be found [40,41]. Research on HAS catalysts has so far mainly been focused on the production of powder catalysts [9–12]. However, these catalysts cannot be applied in industrial fixed-bed reactors due to the high pressure drop [42–44]. The development of shaped catalysts, that are applicable in up-scaled fixed-bed reactors with acceptable pressure drops, is required but systematic approaches and results are scarce. Main reasons for this are the academic knowledge gap in this area described in detail by Mitchell et al. [42], the secrecy of the relevant knowledge in industrial companies and its protection by patents, as well as the interdisciplinary nature of the development processes. Therefore, the challenges of this development process have rarely been addressed in literature. The preparation of shaped iron catalysts for HA synthesis necessitates the addition of a support, often a ceramic material. This material prevents the sintering of the iron particles within the pellet [42,45], allowing a stable operation. For technically more relevant shaped catalysts the only monometallic iron-based catalyst optimized in composition for HAS was recently presented by our group in a comprehensive study [46]. This trilobe-shaped catalyst named 1LiCu-50Fe-Tri composes of 50 wt.-% Fe with 1 wt.-% Li and Cu each (referred to the mass of reduced iron in the catalyst) and α-Al2O3 as the support material. A CO conversion of 14 %, C≥5OH selectivity of 12 % and STY of 5.5 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 could be measured at a comparably low temperature (ϑ = 200 °C) and pressure (20 bar). The cost-effective and easy-to-scale preparation of the catalyst trilobes allows for the application in technical fixed-bed reactors with adequate pressure drop along the catalyst bed. This catalyst was applied in the present work as a basis for the first systematic experimental investigation of the HAS from syngas in a semi-technical reactor. Moreover, the process integration within a Power-to-Liquid concept is discussed and its influence on reactor operation studied in a lab-scale plant. Prior to these reactor tests, a detailed study on the optimization of operating conditions for HA synthesis was conducted applying statistical design of experiment (DoE) methods and linear regression models. The results of the study showed the potential for further increase in STY by adjusting the process conditions. In this context, the influence of CO2 on catalyst performance was evaluated. For the assessment of HAS in a process context, tail gas recirculation was carried out using the novel shaped HA catalyst described in Ref. [46] in a scaled reactor setup. The results of this study represent a further step on the way to application of iron-based catalysts in technically relevant Power-to-Liquid processes. The experiments yield insights into the influence of recirculation on product distribution, STY and stability of the catalyst. 2 Contextualization of the study 2.1 Influence of process conditions on HA synthesis Conversion, selectivity as well as yield and STY in FTS of HA are dependent on the reactions conditions and particularly influenced by reaction temperature, space velocity (SV), pressure and syngas composition. The most relevant process parameter is the temperature. An increase leads to increasing conversion, but to decreasing alcohol selectivity due to increased hydrogenation rate [47]. As the increase in conversion is generally higher than the decrease in alcohol selectivity with increasing temperature, higher operating temperatures are an option to increase yield and STY. However, Fig. 1 highlights a drawback of this approach. Here, literature data on conversion XCO and overall alcohol selectivity SOH for several HA catalysts are plotted. Additionally, the reaction temperature is indicated by color and the fraction of HA (j ≥ 3) among the formed alcohols (2) χ = S C ≥ 3 OH S OH is indicated by the size of the bubbles. Thus, the data in Fig. 1 shows that while high overall alcohol yield can be reached at higher temperatures, the fraction of HA (j ≥ 3) among the produced alcohols is rather low. This is due to the fact that especially long-chain alcohols are converted in secondary reactions [48–50]. HAS performance of specific catalysts is often assessed on the basis of STY, often including ethanol (j = 2) into the definition of HA. This can lead to misleading conclusions. Often catalysts with high STY reached by applying high temperatures mainly produce ethanol. Data on chain length distribution for alcohols – allowing for a more thorough assessment of the catalyst – are often not published. In this work, special emphasis is placed on the production of higher alcohols with chain lengths j ≥ 5. For this purpose, low-temperature FTS in the range of 200–220 °C was found beneficial for the HAS [18,51–55]. In FTS the chain growth of products was found to be increased by increasing pressure [66]. However, operating pressures in the range of 20–40 bar are generally applied, as the costs of compressing the syngas for higher pressures could exceed the benefits [67–69]. When the space velocity (3) SV = V ′ ̇ m Fe , as the ratio of the volume flowrate at the inlet and the iron or catalyst weight decreases, the residence time of the reactants in the bed increases and consequently a higher conversion can be observed in the FTS. However, the probability for readsorption of alcohols and alkenes is increased by increasing residence time and conversion, promoting secondary reactions such as hydrogenation of alcohols and alkenes to alkanes [49,52]. In literature [18,51] and preliminary work, promising selectivities to HA were observed in the FTS for a SV in the range of 0.02–0.09 mL g Fe − 1 s − 1 . In most of the previous studies on FTS to HA either pure CO or pure CO2 hydrogenation have been studied. In case of the far more often considered case of pure CO hydrogenation, the composition of this syngas can be described by the H2/CO ratio Φ, which is most often in the range of Φ = 2. However, technical syngas is a mixture of H2, CO and CO2, usually containing a significant amount of CO2, which can also have an influence on the conversion and selectivity of catalysts in the FTS of HA [51]. Accordingly, this influence was of particular interest in the present work and the parameters (4) Γ = φ C O 2 φ C O 2 + φ CO and (5) Λ = φ H 2 − φ C O 2 φ C O 2 + φ CO were introduced to describe the syngas composition (see Eqs. 4 and 5). CO2 amounts of around 10–15 % [4,7,38,39] and Φ = 1–4 are relevant for technical applications. Based on this, the ranges of 0–0.5 and 0.9–2.5 are of particular interest for the parameters Γ and Λ. When the influence of operating conditions is studied in literature, most often only one operating condition at a time is varied while keeping the other operating conditions constant. This allows for a general understanding of the influence of the specific parameter. However, the resulting standard operating conditions chosen to calculate achieved conversion, selectivity and yield do not necessarily be the optimal conditions for this purpose. With the mentioned approach, in the previous work of the authors [46] a space-time yield of STY = 5.5 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 was found for a shaped iron-based HAS catalyst. Optimization of the operating conditions to increase this yield are advantageous. The derivation of a kinetic model sufficiently describing the influence of operating conditions would be a possible but complex and time-consuming approach. Another approach to simplify the search for favorable operating conditions could be an efficient design of experiment (DoE) study, which was conducted here. Instead of yielding detailed kinetic models linear regression models for the prediction of conversion and selectivity in dependence of the reaction conditions can be derived by this strategy. This approach allows to identify advantageous operating conditions in reasonable time. 2.2 State of the art in monometallic supported iron catalysts Having a specific look at supported monometallic iron catalysts, so far only results on powdered catalysts have been published [34,70–81]. An overview on performance data like conversion, selectivity and STY for monometallic supported iron-based powder catalysts is given in Table 1 together with the respective operating conditions. The results show that – as stated in Ref. [46] – the conducted work on supported monometallic iron catalysts for HAS is rather unsystematic. In all cases these catalysts have been tested in powdered form and, thus, in the absence of any mass transfer limitations. Most data refer to unpromoted catalysts applied either in pure CO or in pure CO2 hydrogenation. The data again highlights some of the points addressed in Section 2.1. The STY is often only reported for j ≥ 2, making it difficult to assess the performance regarding formation of long-chained alcohols. Additionally, the given values are most often achieved via high conversion reached by choosing high temperatures (especially in case of CO2-based synthesis). As outlined above, this increases yield but decreases the formation of long-chained, more valuable alcohols. However, in some cases also promising selectivities have been reached, especially for an In and K promoted catalyst. Here, a promising C≥2OH STY of up to 104 m g C ≥ 2 OH g Kat − 1 h − 1 was found [78], but again chain length distribution of alcohols is not given and chain growth probability can be assumed to be low at the high reactor temperature. As outlined above, all previous work on monometallic supported iron catalysts for HAS is focused on powdered catalysts. Thus, there is no shaped catalyst available that is specifically developed for HAS. Generally looking at shaped iron-based FT catalysts the Ruhrchemie catalyst can still be considered as a reference catalyst, even though it was developed over seventy years ago [66,82,83]. Therefore, this catalyst, was used to benchmark the shaped catalyst optimized for HAS. 2.3 Process integration of HA synthesis As outlined above, the synthesis of HA is focused in the context of sustainable production processes for valuable chemical products. Specifically, it is expected that so-called Power-to-Liquid processes starting from H2O and CO2 as feedstocks will become key steps linking renewable energy production with different sectors [84,85]. Thus, the implications of integrating HA synthesis in such a process concept will be discussed briefly. A general flow scheme of a Power-to-Liquid process is given in Fig. 2. Starting from H2O and CO2, the generation of syngas is the first process step. Generally, there are two different options available: coupling of water electrolysis with an RWGS reaction step or co-electrolysis [4,7,38]. The produced syngas is fed to the Fischer-Tropsch reactor. In terms of overall process efficiency, full conversion of the syngas would be desired. However, the maximum achievable conversion is limited. This is due to the fact that the product water formed at high partial pressures leads to oxidation and, thus, degradation of the catalyst [86]. Additionally, heat removal can become a problem at high conversions in fixed-bed reactors [31,87]. Therefore, per-pass conversion in established large-scale fixed-bed Fischer-Tropsch reactors is often limited to values in the range of 30–50 % [69,88,89]. For the synthesis of HA considered here, high conversions in the reactor also lead to a drop in HA selectivity due to the secondary reactions occurring at the corresponding high temperatures or residence times. Both in established large-scale Fischer-Tropsch plants [47] and in developed Power-to-Liquid concepts [85,90–92], the gas phase remaining after separation of the waxeous and liquid products (hydrocarbons and water) is therefore usually recycled. Depending on the per-pass conversion XCO,FT, this tail gas contains a relevant proportion of unreacted syngas in addition to the gaseous reaction products. Thus, recirculation to the inlet of the reactor can increase the overall conversion XCO,ov. This option is often referred to as short or internal recycle [47,85,91,93]. The separation of water downstream of the reactor reduces degradation. Additionally, in case of HA synthesis, the separation of HA reduces the probability of secondary reactions. However, one disadvantage of short recirculation is the accumulation of some gaseous components in the cycle. In addition to inert substances such as N2, which may be contained in the supplied CO2, the latter can accumulate in the cycle itself. Additionally, short-chain alkanes that are not subject to secondary reactions can also accumulate. The inlet composition of the syngas in the system context thus differs significantly from the syngas compositions usually assumed in lab-scale catalyst testing. In these tests, H2 and CO are often considered as the only reactive components, as mentioned before. In order to limit the enrichment of CO2 and gaseous hydrocarbons, part of the residual gas is usually fed back into the syngas production in a so-called long or external recycle [38,47,93,94]. There, the short-chain hydrocarbons and CO2 can be converted into syngas via reforming and RWGS, respectively [38,69]. However, in order to prevent the accumulation of inert components like N2, part of the gas stream must always be removed from the cycle process as purge gas. This stream can be combusted. The heat integration of this process stage and the exothermic Fischer-Tropsch synthesis are important tasks in the development of Power-to-Liquid processes, which are usually approached using models [69,93]. However, regarding the development of iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts for use in Power-to-Liquid processes, which is the focus here, the short recycle mentioned above is particularly relevant, as only this directly influences the inlet composition in the reactor and thus its performance. In literature, only few experimental studies dealt with the effect of a short recycle on product composition of FT synthesis [95–97]. However, none of the results are applicable to HAS on iron-based catalysts. As recirculation will influence the reactor performance due to accumulation of inerts and secondary reactions of unsaturated hydrocarbons, a study on the influence of a short recycle on the performance of a technically relevant catalyst for HAS is of interest in order to assess the current development status as well as to provide data for a future evaluation of the complete process by means of a techno-economic study. 3 Materials and methods 3.1 Catalyst preparation The detailed procedure for the synthesis of the trilobe catalyst 1LiCu-50Fe-Tri is described elsewhere [46]. Briefly, iron oxide powder was synthesized by co-precipitation from Fe(NO3)3*9H2O (>99 %, Merck) solution and NH3 solution (>28 %, VWR Chemicals) in a 10 L-batch reactor. The derived FeOOH was washed for several times and dried at 120 °C for 48 h in air. Afterwards, it was ground and sieved to grain sizes in the range of 25–100 μm. Calcination was carried out in two steps, heating with a rate of 1 K min−1 to 120 °C, holding for 12 h and subsequently heating with a rate of 2 K min−1 to the final calcination temperature of 700 °C, with a holding period of 4 h. Electrochemical promotion of the iron oxide powder was conducted by incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) applying an aqueous solution of LiNO3 (Merck) and Cu(NO3)2*3H2O (Merck) to set weight fractions of 1 % regarding the mass of elemental iron. The feedstock for catalyst extrusion contained the prepared α-Fe2O3 powder, α-Al2O3 powder (CT1200SG, Almatis) and a multicomponent thermoplastic polyamide-based binder system. The components were homogeneously compounded in a kneader (Hermann Linden Maschinenfabrik GmbH & Co. KG) with a kneading chamber of 2 L volume heated at 150–170 °C. After removal of the compound, it was cooled down to ambient temperature and cut in a cutting mill (Retsch GmbH) to 1–3 mm granulates. This granulate was processed in a continuous twin-screw extruder with six heating zones (Brabender KETSE 20/40) to yield a strand that was automatically deposited on a conveyor belt, cooled and cut to the desired pellet length in a pelletizer. The pellets were debindered in a two-step process. First, solvent debindering was carried out in acetone at 40 °C for 48 h removing low-molecular polymers, followed by drying. Second, to remove the high-molecular polymers thermal debindering was carried out according to a three-step program consisting of water and solvent removal at 120 °C, removal of the organic binder at 600 °C and finally sintering at a temperature of 850 °C for a holding time of 10 min. 3.2 Catalyst characterization The catalyst was comprehensively characterized by various methods such as N2 physisorption, Hg intrusion, inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy, X-ray diffractometry, Mössbauer Spectroscopy, field emission scanning electron microscopy and temperature programmed reduction. The detailed procedures and results for the catalyst characterization as well as mechanical pellet strength are given elsewhere [46]. Briefly, the catalyst had a specific surface area of 1 m2 g−1 determined by BET-method, 42 % porosity determined by Hg intrusion. The intended elemental composition (1 wt.-% Li, 1 wt.-% Cu with respect to Fe + 50 wt.-% Al2O3) was confirmed by ICP-OES and X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy. 3.3 Catalytic testing For catalytic testing two different in-house built, automated test plants were used, that differed in the size and concept of the reactor as well as in the degree of process integration. The small-scale setup applied for the study on optimization of process conditions consisted of gas dosing unit, split tube furnace for heating of the tubular fixed-bed reactor, hot and cold trap for product separation and decompression unit. A flow scheme of this plant can be found in Ref. [46]. For the tests in the small-scale setup 23.65 g of the optimized 50 wt.-% iron catalyst 1LiCu-50Fe-Tri or 15 g of Ruhrchemie catalyst were placed between two layers of SiC (ESK E-Abrasic grün F16) that assured gas preheating in the single-tube reactor with an inner diameter of 15.3 mm. The mass of the samples was chosen to ensure a similar bed length in the reactor. The composition of the Ruhrchemie catalysts is reported to be 100Fe/4.3Cu/4.1 K/25SiO2 [66,82,83]. This was confirmed by ICP-OES and x-ray fluorescence spectroscopy measurements. The specific surface area determined by BET method and porosity determined by Hg intrusion have been found to be around 310 m2 g−1 and 51 %, respectively. Reduction of the catalysts was conducted in-situ under flowing H2 at 300 °C and a pressure of 10 bar for 10 h. Similar conditions have been reported to be beneficial for both the optimized HAS and the Ruhrchemie catalyst [46,66,98]. Subsequently, the catalyst bed was cooled down to 200 °C in a flow of N2 while increasing the pressure to 20 bar. Having reached the operating pressure, syngas dosing was started, leading to carburization of the catalyst and start of FTS. For each test an axial temperature profile along the bed was measured and temperature control of the furnace was set to the highest temperature within the bed [46]. For the optimization of reaction conditions statistical design of experiment was applied. The varied reaction condition parameters temperature, SV, pressure and syngas composition as well as their boundaries were chosen based on the considerations presented in Section 2.1 and are given in Table 2. The time-on-stream (TOS) was included in the study as a parameter in order to account for the influence of degradation. The catalyst was investigated according to a fractional factorial experimental design, that was set up using the Software Minitab. The plan was split in three separate test series, each started with fresh catalyst, to ensure reproducibility and increase statistical accuracy of the tests by referencing the standard operating point (SOP; 200 °C, 20 bar, 0.06 mL, Γ = 0, Λ = 2) in the beginning of each series. A total amount of 63 operating condition sets was investigated including repetitions of the SOP and other reference points. The evaluation of all the catalytic test results in this study was followed by an explorative, qualitative data analysis to check the plausibility of the results. No unusual observations were found, and all data sets could be processed in the Minitab software to yield linear regression equations of the type (6) X CO , mod = K 0 + K 1 * ϑ + K 2 * p + K 3 * SV + K 4 * Γ + K 5 * Λ + K 6 * TOS + K 7 * ϑ * p + K 8 * ϑ * SV + … + K 21 * Λ * TOS + σ for the prediction of selected target variables. The parametrized constants are represented by K0 to K21. In addition to the model for CO conversion models for selectivities to alcohols, alkenes and alkanes of different chain length as well as for CO2 were parametrized. At first, all the possible one-factor and two-factor effects were used for parametrization of the linear regression models. Afterwards, a backward elimination algorithm was used to stepwise remove the most insignificant effect and re-parametrize the regression equation iteratively till all remaining effects were found significant. For the model derived by backward elimination the resulting regression equations with the corresponding constants are given in Table A1. In contrast to the small-scale FT plant with a tubular fixed-bed reactor the reactor of the up-scaled FT plant ( Fig. 3) had four parallel slit-like catalyst beds with 100 mL volume each [38]. In total 150 g of shaped catalyst 1LiCu-50Fe-Tri were packed between two layers of SiC (ESK E-Abrasic grün F16). The reactor was heated by a circulation thermostat (Julabo HT30) with silicone oil (Julabo Thermal H350) as the thermal fluid. Reduction and carburization were conducted as described above. During FTS, temperature within the catalyst bed was monitored by four thermocouples per chamber. For control of the reactor heating, the thermocouple with the highest temperature was chosen. After the separation of waxeous and liquid products in the hot and cold trap, the process gas stream was decompressed either into the vent or a 4 L buffer tank. From this volume, a compressed air-driven two-stage compressor (Maximator DLE 5) fed part of the tail gas back into the FT reactor. The mass flow of the recycled gas and the purge gas were measured. By adjusting the recycle gas flow by a mass flow controller (Bronkhorst mini Cori-Flow) it was possible to set a certain recycle ratio (7) R = V ̇ rec ′ V ̇ purge ′ + V ̇ rec ′ that can be calculated as the ratio of the recycled flow rate and the total flowrate at the reactor outlet. By online GC measurement (Inficon Fusion GC) the purge gas composition could be determined. Based on this, the feed streams of H2 and CO could be adjusted to keep a constant ratio of H2/CO = 2 for all investigated recycle ratios in range from 60–95 %. 3.4 Product analysis Composition of the decompressed gas phase was monitored online by a µGC (Inficon Fusion GC, equipped with RT-Molsieve, RT-Q-Bond and RXi-1ms column modules with integrated thermal conductivity detector) applying N2 as an internal standard. Gaseous reactants and products could be quantified, which allowed for the confirmation of stationary operation. As soon as the steady state was reached, but at least 20 h after start of syngas dosing, hot and cold vessels operated at 180 °C and 0 °C, respectively, were emptied and a balancing period of 24–48 h began. The balancing period was finished by emptying the hot and cold vessels. Phase separation of aqueous and liquid hydrocarbon phase was conducted for the samples received from the cold trap. The internal standards cyclohexane (liquid hydrocarbon sample), 1,4-dioxane (aqueous sample) and toluene (wax sample dissolved in cyclohexane) were added for the quantification of more than 300 hydrocarbons and oxygenates by GC (Agilent 7980B: H2 carrier gas, 100 m RTX-1 column, flame ionization detector (FID), liquid hydrocarbon and aqueous sample; Varian CP-3800: He carrier gas, 50 m DB-5 column, FID, wax sample). The amounts of each substance in different product phases were summed up and the carbon balance could be closed to > 95 % for every operating point, confirming the accuracy of the analysis. 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Optimization of operating conditions In order to identify promising, industrially relevant operating points for the operation of a scalable FT plant for HAS, the shaped catalyst presented by Medicus et al. [46] was tested in a small-scale tubular reactor in the parameter range presented in Table 2 applying a DoE approach. A comparison of the catalytic results at the SOP in the beginning of the three test series is shown in Fig. 4. The conversion and selectivities are in good agreement, which is a basic requirement for the reliability of the DoE results and gives evidence for the reproducibility of the experimental work. Conversion and product distribution are compared in Fig. 4 at the end of two of the test series as well. After 1435 h and 730 h, respectively, significant deviations from the initial catalytic results were detected in both test series, which was due to deactivation of the catalyst. The formation of HA was strongly affected by deactivation while the selectivity for long-chain hydrocarbons remained almost unchanged. In previously documented experiments with a TOS of 240 h or 300 h under constant reaction conditions, constant conversion and slightly increasing selectivity to HA was observed with increasing TOS [99,100]. In contrast to that deactivation was more pronounced in the experiments carried out here due to the significantly longer TOS up to 1435 h and, above all, due to the numerous changes in operating conditions during the statistical test plan. The catalyst was exposed to increased CO2 partial pressures and, at high conversion rates, also significant water partial pressures, which could cause oxidation and hydrothermal sintering of the catalyst and active centers. The faster deactivation of the catalyst during test series 2 might be due to a significant contribution of CO2 in the syngas. In test series 2, an average of 10 % CO2 was dosed at 20 of the 23 test points, compared to an average of 7 % CO2 at a total of 20 test points in test series 1 (Table A2). In addition, the average H2 content was higher in test series 1, which could have counteracted oxidative deactivation. Structural changes of the catalyst phase composition due to the deactivation were investigated by Mössbauer spectroscopy and gave evidence for an oxidative mechanism. A significantly higher fraction of oxidic iron (68 %) was detected for the catalyst used for 1435 h compared to the regenerated catalyst (36 %). The proportion of χ-Fe5C2 amounted to 9 % and 31 % and that of ε-Fe2C to 20 % and 28 %, respectively ( Table 3). Therefore, it could be concluded that the stability of the χ-Fe5C2 phase under the selected operating conditions is lower than that of the ε-Fe2C phase and it is more affected by deactivation due to oxidation. This is in agreement with results documented by Smit et al. [101]. In contrast to the selectivity for long-chain hydrocarbons the selectivity to HA had strongly decreased after 1435 h and 730 h (Fig. 4), which is an indication for the important function of the χ-Fe5C2 phase in the alcohol formation. After regeneration, a significantly increased amount of χ-Fe5C2 could be detected again (Table 3) and alcohol selectivity as well as conversion could be almost fully recovered (820 h TOS, Fig. 4). This is further evidence for the importance of χ-Fe5C2 for the formation of HA in the FTS and supports results from other authors [51,76,102,103]. Additionally, it could be proved that catalyst lifetime can be extended by regular regeneration steps allowing lower frequency of catalyst replacement in technical applications and thus savings in operating costs. In a technical application the catalyst would also be applied under stationary conditions that would lead to decreased deactivation. In Fig. 5 the comparison of experimentally determined values of CO conversion and HA selectivity with values predicted by the derived linear regression models is given. The target variables can be predicted with a relative accuracy of around 25 %, whereby the average relative deviation of the predicted value from the measured value is around 10 %. Even though the accuracy of the model is limited, especially for the selectivity to HA, it has to be kept in mind that the purpose of this rather simple model was not the exact description of the product composition but rather the identification of a valuable range of operating conditions increasing the HA yield. With the parametrized model, the optimization function of Minitab was applied to identify operating conditions with maximized yield within the defined range. For that purpose, TOS was set to a value of 100 h, as this corresponds to the usual time for determining the catalytic activity of a fresh catalyst. Applying this approach, the operating condition combination A listed in Table 4 was obtained. A C≥5OH selectivity of 13 % was predicted. The calculation of further target variables such as conversion, selectivity to long-chain alkanes ( S C ≥ 5 ane ) and alkenes ( S C ≥ 5 e ne ) could be carried out for this test point using the regression equations derived for these variables (Table A2) as well. In particular, the STY of C≥5OH at point A was promising and exceeded the previously reported value of 5.5 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 [46]. At that operating point for temperature and Γ the lower boundary conditions were suggested, while values of the upper boundaries for SV and pressure were derived. In general, this is in agreement with the general trends revealed in one-factor at a time approaches and described in Section 2.1. From the prediction it can be concluded that by further increasing the pressure STY could be even further increased. However, for extension of the parameter range to higher pressures economic considerations should be made because investment costs for the reactor and operating costs for gas compression are strongly increasing with operating pressure. The same applies to SV and temperature. Here, the low overall conversion would be detrimental, as the cost for syngas generation and recycling would need to be accounted for. Overall, a comprehensive optimization of operating conditions can only be done when the economic dimension is accounted for. However, this is beyond the scope of this work. Thus, the approach followed here should especially highlight the potential of a targeted manipulation of operating conditions for HA synthesis. As expected, CO2-free syngas is proposed by the model for the optimized set of operating conditions A, due to the negative effect of CO2 on the HA selectivity. Since its influence on the HA yield and STY is of particular interest and its presence is to be expected in technical syngas, target values were also predicted for the case of approximately 10 % CO2 (Γ = 0.3) in the syngas while holding temperature, pressure and SV constant at the conditions of point A (Table 4B). The derived results B gave evidence of the negative effect of CO2 on the selectivity to higher hydrocarbons and alcohols. Although the measured CO conversion is increased, the STY of HA is significantly decreased compared to HAS with CO2-free syngas, which is due to the lowered absolute CO amount in the syngas feed. In a validation experiment with fresh catalyst the operating points A and B were tested within a TOS of 100–200 h, so that the influence of deactivation in this narrow time frame could be assumed to be low. Data on conversion and selectivity are given in Fig. 6 compared to the predicted values. The accuracy of the predictions could be confirmed within the expected deviation boundaries of up to ± 25 %. Consequently, the purpose of these models of allowing reasonable estimations of the catalytic performance in a wide range of operating conditions without having investigated the detailed kinetics was fulfilled. Based on the models, an operating point with elevated STY of HA could be identified for the optimized shaped catalyst. With 9.2 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 the STY exceeded the STY of 5.5 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 [46] determined at the SOP. The observed increase was mainly due to the increase in total pressure at constant SV, which significantly increased the reaction rate. Further increases in the reaction pressure could lead to a further improvement. However, extending the parameter space in this way should also be considered from an economic point of view, as discussed above. As outlined above, no reference data from literature is available for proper comparison. Published data refers to powdered catalysts tested at different operating conditions. But foremost, the limited differentiation of the produced HA according to chain length makes a profound comparison impossible. Therefore, to benchmark the shaped catalyst optimized in composition and reaction conditions for the HAS it was compared to the Ruhrchemie catalyst at the same activation and operation conditions. The results are given in Fig. 7. Although the initial surface area of the Ruhrchemie catalyst with approximately 300 m2 g−1 was significantly higher compared to the shaped catalyst optimized for HAS with only approx. 1 m2 g−1, the conversion was lower at all operating points. In addition, the activity in WGS reaction and, thus, the selectivity to CO2 was significantly increased for the Ruhrchemie catalyst due to the high weight fraction of potassium [66,82,83]. The low CO2 selectivity of the developed catalyst would have a positive effect on the economics of an associated Power-to-Liquid process. The selectivity for HA was in a similar range, but at the optimized operating point A for the Ruhrchemie catalyst only 10 % C≥5OH selectivity could be measured compared to 14 % for the LiCu-promoted catalyst. A comprehensive overview of the alcohol chain length distribution and chain growth probability are given in Fig. A1 for both catalysts under comparable reaction conditions. The chain growth probability αOH for the optimized catalyst was in the range of 0.75–0.77 even when CO2 was present in the syngas. Therefore, it could be derived, that CO2 has a significant influence on the selectivity at all but does only slightly influence the chain growth probability of alcohols. The chain growth probability for the other product classes, especially the alkenes, was also significantly lower when using the Ruhrchemie catalyst. Although the conventional Ruhrchemie catalyst still represents the benchmark in the field of iron-based low- and middle-temperature FTS since the 1960s, the shaped catalyst investigated here is not only more suitable for the HAS but also for the synthesis of long-chain alkenes as base chemicals. The conversion of these long-chain alkenes to HA in an integrated process could help to further increase the HA yield and improve economics of the process. Approaches for this purpose have been already demonstrated on laboratory scale [104,105]. Additionally, the preparation of the optimized HAS catalyst is less complex in comparison to the one for the Ruhrchemie catalyst [66]. As outlined above, there is no data on STY for alcohols with j ≥ 5 available for supported catalysts. However, from reported data on unsupported powdered catalysts respective values can be derived. Despite the improvement in STY to 9.2 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 achieved for the shaped supported catalyst in the present work it was well below the STY of more than 300 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 , 100 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 and 70 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 presented for CoCu, CuFe and Fe catalysts [19,20,106]. However, as mentioned above these values were found for powdered unsupported catalysts. These catalysts are not influenced by diffusion limitations. Furthermore, no inert support needs to be accounted for in calculating the STY. However, these powdered catalysts cannot be applied in typical fixed-bed reactors. Additionally, the CO2 selectivity of the bimetallic systems is at a level ≥ 30 %, which is significantly higher than for the shaped catalyst applied here. 4.2 Process integration As the shaped catalyst developed here is promising for the implementation in Power-to-Liquid systems, the implications of such a process integration, i.e. tail gas recirculation, were studied. An upscaled laboratory plant was used for this purpose. In general, two aspects were investigated in the course of the experiments: first, the reproducibility of the results obtained on the smaller laboratory plant in the tubular fixed-bed reactor; and second, the potential of process integration by means of process gas recirculation for increasing the overall conversion. An overview of the operating conditions applied during testing as well as of the resulting catalytic performance is given in Fig. A2. In part 1 of this test series the accuracy and transferability of the regression models determined before in the small-scale tubular fixed-bed reactor were evaluated during the statistical variation of temperature, SV and H2/CO ratio without process gas recycling. In contrast to the DoE study presented in Section 4.1, the pressure was hold constant (20 bar), because of the lower design pressure of the scaled system. A conversion of 7 % was reached at the SOP in the scaled reactor ( Fig. 8B1). This was significantly lower than for the tubular reactor with 14 % (Fig. 8A) and caused by differences in the flow and temperature distribution in the reactor. The flow profile in the scaled reactor was significantly more complex than in a tubular reactor, which means that there was a possibility of uneven reactant distribution. In addition, more pronounced temperature gradients occurred than in the tubular reactor. As the reactor was always controlled according to the highest temperature measured, an uneven temperature distribution over the bed led to lower temperatures in some part of the reactor. This not only affected activity during FTS. It might also lead to an incomplete reduction during the reductive catalyst pretreatment. Thus, not only conversion was affected by the temperature distribution within the bed. Therefore, at the SOP a lower C≥5OH selectivity of 9 % was observed at the scaled reactor compared to the small-scale tubular reactor with 12 % (Fig. 8). A maximum C≥5OH selectivity of 10 % could be reached in the scaled setup at 200 °C at reduced SV ( Table 5). As expected, with increasing temperature, SV and H2/CO ratio, an increase in STY up to 2.2 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 was observed (Table 5), which was significantly lower than for the tubular reactor (Table 4). This was due to the limited reaction pressure and the mentioned inhomogeneities in reactant flow and temperature distribution. The HA yield decreased with increasing STY, which underlines the necessary trade-off between the objectives of decreasing reactor size and increasing the yield. The latter target value could be positively influenced by lowering the SV and the associated increase in conversion to 29 % (Table 5). In the technical implementation of FTS it is typically aimed for a per-pass conversion of 30–50 % in the reactor [69,88,89]. To increase the utilization of syngas tail gas usually is recycled. The results presented above showed that even for promising HA selectivities of more than 10 % conversion was limited to a maximum value of around 20 % for the shaped catalyst (Fig. 6). Consequently, the potential of tail gas recirculation needs to be evaluated. Therefore, the recycle ratio R was varied in the range of 60–95 % in part 2 of the test series at the scaled reactor setup. As there was no separation step for CO2 formed due to WGS in the process, it was accumulated in the reactor as R was increased, causing Γ and Λ to vary, as depicted in Fig. A2. As shown before (Table 4) a negative effect of CO2 on conversion and selectivity is to be expected. First, the recycle ratio was varied from 0.6–0.95 while maintaining the other operating conditions constant ( Fig. 9). The overall process conversion XCO,ov was increased with increasing recycle ratio, whereby the per-pass conversion in the reactor XCO,FT was reduced from 6 % to 5 % (Fig. 9). This can be ascribed to the increasing fraction of inert products in the inlet feed stream, as discussed below. At a constant temperature of 200 °C and SV of 0.06 mL g Fe − 1 s − 1 XCO,ov could be increased from 6 % without recirculation to up to 44 % at R = 0.95. The selectivities remained almost constant over a wide range up to R = 0.8. Above this recycle ratio, the alkene selectivity decreased significantly and the selectivity to short-chain alcohols and alkanes increased. This could be due to secondary reactions as hydrogenation of short-chain alkenes to alkanes as well as renewed CO insertion or hydroformylation with subsequent desorption as alcohol [51,107–109]. Since the STY of HA correlates with the per-pass conversion in the reactor, it was decreased from 1.4 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 to 0.9 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 when increasing the recycle ratio. By reducing the SV to 0.03 mL g Fe − 1 s − 1 , an overall conversion of 72 % was measured at R = 0.95. This was the highest overall conversion and, with an HA selectivity of 7 %, the highest HA yield of around 5 % achieved in this work. The increase in conversion was accompanied by a further decrease in selectivity to alkenes due to readsorption and secondary reactions of these molecules. The CO conversion in the reactor was 9 % in the recycle process compared to 12 % in normal operation, which could be attributed to the reactant depletion and accumulation of reaction products in the reactor causing an inhibited reaction rate. At the reactor inlet, the gas feed contained around 20 % of reaction products consisting of 8 % CO2, 6 % CH4, 2 % C2H6, 2 % propene and 2 % propane. For a SV of 0.06 mL g Fe − 1 s − 1 and R = 0.95, the total proportion of reaction products at the reactor inlet was 8 % (3 % CO2, 2 % CH4, 1 % C2H6, 1 % propene and 1 % propane). Thus, the accumulation of CO2 and CH4 in the system was significantly dependent on the recycle ratio and overall conversion. In addition to a decrease in XCO,FT, this also caused the decrease of STY from 1.4 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 to 0.8 m g C ≥ 5 OH g c at − 1 h − 1 for a recycle ratio increasing from 0–0.95 and a SV of 0.03 mL g Fe − 1 s − 1 . In an overall process context CO2 separation prior to recirculation would be an option to be assessed, to reduce the accumulation of this byproduct. However, this would be associated with additional cost for the separation step. Thus, the implications of such an approach must be studied in a techno-economic assessment on plant level. At an elevated reaction temperature of 210 °C, a decrease in alkene selectivity was observed for an increasing recycle ratio up to 0.95 and total conversion up to 63 %, while the selectivity to alkanes was increased. The selectivity to HA decreased to 4 %. Consequently, the HA yield of 2.5 % remained below the yield of 5 % achieved at 200 °C in the recycle process. These results again highlight the point raised in Section 2 that increasing temperature as a means of increasing STY is problematic. Applying the definition of HA applied in other works with j ≥ 2, the STY would increase from 3.1 m g C ≥ 2 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 (SV = 0.06 mL g Fe − 1 s − 1 , R = 0.95, ϑ = 200 °C) to 3.5 m g C ≥ 2 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 (SV = 0.06 mL g Fe − 1 s − 1 , R = 0.95, ϑ = 210 °C). However, as already stated above, the STY for the considerably more valuable alcohols with j ≥ 5 decreases by almost 50 %. Again, one can conclude that proper definition of HA, a more thorough breakdown of product distribution in publications as well as the expansion of the analysis to include an economic dimension are necessary for a comprehensive assessment of catalysts and the resulting processes. By this experimental study it could be confirmed that the conversion in an integrated process with process gas recirculation can be increased to a technically relevant level. The selectivity to alkanes and alcohols as well as to CO2 remained almost constant over the entire conversion range, while the selectivity to alkenes decreased with increasing recycle ratio and total conversion. The reason for this was that short-chain alkenes were also circulated with the process gas and could be readsorbed on the catalyst and hydrogenated to alkanes in subsequent reactions. There was also indication of secondary reactions of alkenes to alcohols. An increased occurrence of secondary reactions of alcohols could not be observed, as these products were almost completely separated in the cold trap and were not recycled. This is a decisive advantage over a reactor designed to achieve the same conversion without process gas recirculation but with a higher residence time, in which secondary reactions of alcohols would occur more frequently with increasing conversion along the fixed-bed [49,51,52]. During the recirculation of tail gas, there was no change in CO2 selectivity or indication of RWGS reaction taking place, even with an enrichment of up to 8 % CO2 at the reactor inlet. This was in agreement with the investigations carried out in the DoE study in Section 4.1. The highest overall conversion and the best HA yield to date of 72 % and 5 % in the iron-based FTS of HA were achieved by process gas recirculation. It was shown that process gas recirculation in the FTS of HA mainly affected overall conversion and, therefore, the yield. However, as per-pass conversion is rather low, high recycle ratios are necessary to achieve high overall conversions. This is of course detrimental to process economics. In general, there is the potential to increase per-pass conversion by increasing the temperature, at the cost of a reduced selectivity to valuable HA with j ≥ 5. So, a design trade-off results that cannot be specified from the data provided here. In a next step, process modeling and economic modeling for the overall process would need to be applied. With such a techno-economic assessment it would be possible to identify the most suitable operating conditions for the synthesis by maximizing the revenue of the process. In this context also the influence of additional process steps like CO2 separation or alkene hydroformylation could be assessed. Of course, this is beyond the scope of this paper, but the presented results and models might be included into such a model. Addressing the challenges of this overall process assessment is the scope of future research. 5 Conclusion A shaped iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalyst optimized for HAS was investigated in a design of experiment approach to identify promising reaction conditions of technical relevance. From the experimental data linear regression models for the prediction of conversion and selectivity in dependence of reaction conditions and TOS were derived. In good agreement with the model, a promising STY of 9.2 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 was achieved in absence of CO2 in the syngas feed while under similar reaction conditions but in the presence of CO2 only 5.3 m g C ≥ 5 OH g cat − 1 h − 1 could be reached. Deactivation was observed during the test series and could be attributed to oxidation of the catalyst. However, initial conversion and selectivity were found to be fully recovered by an intermediate reductive regeneration step. The optimized catalyst has been compared to the Ruhrchemie catalyst, that is the state-of-the-art for low- and middle-temperature FTS, under similar reaction conditions. Higher selectivities and space-time yields to alcohols and alkenes could be reached with the optimized shaped catalyst highlighting the success in the comprehensive optimization of catalyst composition and reaction conditions. Furthermore, the application of the optimized catalyst in an integrated process with tail gas recirculation was investigated. The overall process conversion could be increased up to 72 % by increasing the recycle ratio to 0.95. The selectivity to HA remained constant over a wide range of recycle ratios. However, the per-pass conversion in the reactor and the process space-time yield were decreasing with increasing recycle ratio due to accumulation of gaseous products in the reactor. The comprehensive data received should be used for process modeling of a Power-to-Liquid process towards HA. This assessment should include the consideration of process economics as well as the evaluation of other consecutive reaction steps such as the use of alkenes produced during FTS for the hydroformylation or hydration to alcohols. The evaluation on process level would also allow for a suitable trade-off regarding operating conditions like temperature to be identified. Thus, beneficial parameters for cost-efficient HA synthesis can be identified from an economic perspective. The experimental results as well as the simple model provided here could be used for that purpose. CRediT authorship contribution statement Johannes Abel: Resources, Methodology. coredata.dc:description: Chemical industry is facing an upcoming transition from fossil to renewable carbon feedstocks such as CO2. In this context, processes yielding value-added chemicals are of special interest. For the production of higher alcohols (C≥5), iron-based catalysts have been found to be promising. Herein a design of experiment study for the optimization of the space-time yield in dependence of the reaction conditions was conducted for a technically relevant shaped iron-based catalyst optimized for higher alcohol synthesis. In this context also the influence of CO2 on the catalytic performance was studied. In order to allow for an assessment of the catalyst performance in a Power-to-Liquid process, the influence of tail gas recirculation on selectivity and yield was evaluated in a scaled-up test plant. The results presented here provide valuable data for an upcoming techno-economic assessment of the whole Power-to-Liquid process chain.
